title: Session Fixation

activities.message: When is this going to get triaged?
activities.markdown_message: When is this going to get triaged?

activities.message:
Hi,

Thanks for your report. Unfortunately, marking this as a duplicate.

Another researcher reported the following bug:
"Hey there i found out that your cookies are actually being fixed before an after login this allows an attacker to perform a sessino fixation attack and hijack the user's session by capturing the cookies before logging in of the user and replaying it afterwars.

Here are my fixed cookies"

Best,
Weina

Here are my fixed cookies"

Weina

activities.message: This is a different way of session fixation and not the traditional way. If this is being marked as Duplicate, has the previous one been fixed? Have you read my description? The description pasted above is too vague and makes me feel that it is implying the normal way of fixating session cookies which is NOT what I describe above.

Thanks for the report. We've filed a ticket internally to reproduce the error and release a patch for it. We will contact you shortly if we require more information or with any updates.

activities.message:
Hi,

This is a quick update to everyone to has submitted an issue - we are a bit overwhelmed with the initial response to the launch of our HackerOne bug bounty program, and are continuing to go through all of your tickets. We appreciate your patience as we investigate and triage all of your submissions.

Best,
WePay Team

activities.message:
Hi,

I don't quite understand how an attacker can use this vulnerability to hijack a user's account. Can you please explain further? Thanks.
activities.markdown_message:
Hi,

I don't quite understand how an attacker can use this vulnerability to hijack a user's account. Can you please explain further? Thanks.

activities.message:
Sure, let me try..

Assuming a shared workstation scenario.

In a typical session fixation attack, an attacker would navigate to the vulnerable application from a browser on the shared workstation, get a session cookie assigned from the server *without* authenticating to the app, record that cookie and then leave that workstation. 

When the victim comes and navigates to the same vulnerable application and authenticates to it, the session cookie assigned previously is sent along with that authentication request. The server does not update or change this cookie in the response after authenticating the victim and assigns the same value back in the response.  

But, since the attacker already has that value with him, he can use it on a different workstation and hijack a victim's account. Right? This is how a normal Session Fixation attack would work.

Now, for this issue reported here (slightly different version):

I further contemplated as to how an attacker can possibly hijack a user's session. It seems to me that the exploitability is difficult indeed and not as trivial as a typical session fixation attack. For this attack, an attacker would need 2 conditions:
1. An existing authenticated victim session. 
2. An ability to somehow strip off the User-Agent header. 

For example, in a corporate setup, if requests from user workstations are being proxied by an upstream proxy, a malicious admin/attacker can potentially create a config rule to strip off all the User-Agent headers for requests going outbound to the WePay server. As a result, all the existing WePay user sessions would be rendered invalid. 

The malicious admin/attacker would then go to the user workstations (assuming they are being called by users to troubleshoot what went wrong), capture the WePay session ID from the browser and come back. He would then disable the above mentioned rule. Now, if the users authenticate to WePay again, that same session cookie would be sent along with a proper User-Agent header and in response, the WePay server would not update/change the session cookie.

But, since the malicious admin/attacker has that value now, he can then use it on his workstation to hijack a WePay user's session.

PS - I know the above described scenario is hypothetical and not trivial. It assumes a few things which I have not tried in a real world scenario. But, I just wanted to give this attack a little bit of practical exploitation perspective. I hope it makes sense. 

Thanks,
Anshuman
activities.markdown_message:
Sure, let me try..

Assuming a shared workstation scenario.

In a typical session fixation attack, an attacker would navigate to the vulnerable application from a browser on the shared workstation, get a session cookie assigned from the server without authenticating to the app, record that cookie and then leave that workstation.

When the victim comes and navigates to the same vulnerable application and authenticates to it, the session cookie assigned previously is sent along with that authentication request. The server does not update or change this cookie in the response after authenticating the victim and assigns the same value back in the response.

But, since the attacker already has that value with him, he can use it on a different workstation and hijack a victim's account. Right? This is how a normal Session Fixation attack would work.

Now, for this issue reported here (slightly different version):

I further contemplated as to how an attacker can possibly hijack a user's session. It seems to me that the exploitability is difficult indeed and not as trivial as a typical session fixation attack. For this attack, an attacker would need 2 conditions:

  1. An existing authenticated victim session.
  2. An ability to somehow strip off the User-Agent header.

For example, in a corporate setup, if requests from user workstations are being proxied by an upstream proxy, a malicious admin/attacker can potentially create a config rule to strip off all the User-Agent headers for requests going outbound to the WePay server. As a result, all the existing WePay user sessions would be rendered invalid.

The malicious admin/attacker would then go to the user workstations (assuming they are being called by users to troubleshoot what went wrong), capture the WePay session ID from the browser and come back. He would then disable the above mentioned rule. Now, if the users authenticate to WePay again, that same session cookie would be sent along with a proper User-Agent header and in response, the WePay server would not update/change the session cookie.

But, since the malicious admin/attacker has that value now, he can then use it on his workstation to hijack a WePay user's session.

PS - I know the above described scenario is hypothetical and not trivial. It assumes a few things which I have not tried in a real world scenario. But, I just wanted to give this attack a little bit of practical exploitation perspective. I hope it makes sense.

Thanks,
Anshuman

activities.message: Thanks for reporting this issue. We are soon pushing the fix for this to production! As soon as it is live (should be a couple of days), we will update this ticket. Thanks for your help in making WePay safer for its users.
activities.markdown_message: Thanks for reporting this issue. We are soon pushing the fix for this to production! As soon as it is live (should be a couple of days), we will update this ticket. Thanks for your help in making WePay safer for its users.

activities.message: Hello - I am not sure if the fix for this has been implemented or not. You said it would take a couple of days but there has been no update here for almost a week now. I want to let you know that I have requested public disclosure for this issue so you might want to push the fix within the next 22 days before it goes live.
activities.markdown_message: Hello - I am not sure if the fix for this has been implemented or not. You said it would take a couple of days but there has been no update here for almost a week now. Seems like the push for this fix to production was delayed to add more tests. Should be live in two weeks. Sorry for the wait.

vulnerability_information_html:
So, this is not the usual session fixation vulnerability but a slightly weird version of it. Nevertheless, I believe this should be fixed.

Please follow the instructions below to repro this:

  1. Start a proxy tool such as Burp.

  2. Authenticate to the application.

  3. Capture a request to the URL which looks something like https://stage.wepay.com/account_ajax/get_summary_view/<redacted>

  4. Send it to the Repeater tab in Burp. Replay it and make sure a valid response is received.

  5. Now, remove the User-Agent header from this request and replay it. Notice that now, the same valid response received in Step 4 above is no longer received. If you follow the redirection, you will be taken back to the login page.

  6. To confirm, refresh the user session in the browser and notice that you are being asked to login again. So, basically on removing the User-Agent header, something triggered on the server side which essentially made this session invalid. And, you can no longer use this session cookie to access the application.

  7. Now, authenticate to the application again from the browser. Notice the login request in Burp. Observe that wepay-session-uid is the same in the request as well as in the response. See screenshots attached.

  8. To confirm, resend the captured request in Step 4 above (with the User-Agent header) and observe that a valid response is now received.

Although the session cookie does get updated in a normal login-logout-login flow, this flow (removing the User-Agent header) does not update the session cookie which might potentially expose the application to being exploited in similar ways as to how an attacker would exploit a normal session fixation vulnerability.

Cheers,
Anshuman
vulnerability_information:
So, this is not the usual session fixation vulnerability but a slightly weird version of it. Nevertheless, I believe this should be fixed.

Please follow the instructions below to repro this:
1. Start a proxy tool such as Burp.

2. Authenticate to the application.

3. Capture a request to the URL which looks something like https://stage.wepay.com/account_ajax/get_summary_view/<redacted>

4. Send it to the Repeater tab in Burp. Replay it and make sure a valid response is received.

5. Now, remove the User-Agent header from this request and replay it. Notice that now, the same valid response received in Step 4 above is no longer received. If you follow the redirection, you will be taken back to the login page. 

6. To confirm, refresh the user session in the browser and notice that you are being asked to login again. So, basically on removing the User-Agent header, something triggered on the server side which essentially made this session invalid.   And, you can no longer use this session cookie to access the application.

7. Now, authenticate to the application again from the browser. Notice the login request in Burp. Observe that wepay-session-uid is the same in the request as well as in the response. See screenshots attached. 

8. To confirm, resend the captured request in Step 4 above (with the User-Agent header) and observe that a valid response is now received. 

Although the session cookie does get updated in a normal login-logout-login flow, this flow (removing the User-Agent header) does not update the session cookie which might potentially expose the application to being exploited in similar ways as to how an attacker would exploit a normal session fixation vulnerability. 

Cheers,
Anshuman
